content:
The "Energy Fraud and Fairness Reform Act" requires the Federal Trade Commission to investigate gasoline price manipulation within 30 days of enactment and report to Congress within 90 days. The Act also includes tax provisions. The tax provisions in the "Energy Fraud and Fairness Reform Act" include an increase in the credit for alternative fuel vehicle refueling property from 30% to 50%. Additionally, a new credit is introduced for converting gas and diesel vehicles to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells. The "Energy Fraud and Fairness Reform Act" includes a new credit for converting gas and diesel vehicles to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells. A tax credit is allowed for the costs of converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells, as long as the vehicle is used by the taxpayer and not for resale. The conversion must be from a gasoline or diesel vehicle to one using alternative fuel. The tax credit applies to converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells. The definitions of alternative fuel, clean fuel, fuel cell, and motor vehicle are provided in the legislation. The credit can be part of the general business credit if the property is depreciable. The tax credit for converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells is treated as a credit listed in section 38(b) for the taxable year. The credit allowed under subsection (a) shall be treated as a credit allowable under subpart A for the taxable year, with limitations based on the amount of tax. The tax credit for converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells is subject to special rules. These rules include basis reduction and recapture of the credit if the property is no longer eligible. The tax credit for converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells is subject to special rules. No credit is allowed for property used outside the United States or if the taxpayer elects not to apply the credit. Additionally, no double benefit is allowed if a credit is already claimed under another section for the same vehicle. The tax credit for converting a motor vehicle to run on alternative fuel, clean fuel, or fuel cells is subject to special rules. The credit cannot be claimed if the property is used outside the United States or if the taxpayer chooses not to apply the credit. Additionally, no double benefit is allowed if a credit is already claimed under another section for the same vehicle. Amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Code to include the motor vehicle conversion credit as part of the general business credit. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding motor vehicle conversion credits, including changes to Section 6501(m) and the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. Section 30D allows for the conversion of gas and diesel vehicles to alternative fuel or fuel cells. The amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2008. Title III focuses on a refinery capacity study. TITLE III--REFINERY CAPACITY STUDY

SEC. 301. REFINERY CAPACITY STUDY.

Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on a study of US refinery capacity. The study will examine the impact of refinery capacity on gasoline prices, barriers to building and operating refineries, including potential collusion among oil companies, and how Federal funding to oil companies affects domestic oil supply.
